results.name: Pick digits at the even distance from the least significant end of the ternary expansion of n, then convert back to decimal.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..728
Kevin Ryde, Plot2 of X=A163325,Y=A163326, illustrating the ternary Z-order curve.
Index entries for sequences related to coordinates of 2D curves
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k>=0} {A030341(n,k)*b(k)} where b is the sequence (1,0,3,0,9,0,27,0,81,0,243,0... = A254006): powers of 3 alternating with zeros. - _Philippe Deléham_, Oct 22 2011
example: 11 in ternary base (A007089) is written as '102' (1*9 + 0*3 + 2), from which we pick the "zeroth" and 2nd digits from the right, giving '12' = 1*3 + 2 = 5, thus a(11) = 5.
xref: A059905 is an analogous sequence for binary.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 29 2009
ext: Edited by _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Nov 01 2009
